text:
Latency time is the same important metric as elapsed time. However it's logged 
in XML output file only for now. Can you include it in CSV output file as well 
as in summary/aggregate reports ? That will be very helpful for JMeter users.

Thanks.
creator: tongj@cbc.ca

text:
Can certainly add the column to the CSV output.

It would be OK to add average/min/max etc latency, but a single latency column
would not be much use - which should it be?

Adding all these extra columns would make the report very busy. Perhaps a better
solution would be to be able to choose between elapsed and latency for
populating the avg/min/max etc columns?
creator: sebb@apache.org

text:
I think that's a great idea. To allow user to choose the time they want to 
track upon their situation should be always welcome.
creator: tongj@cbc.ca
marcelojara@hotmail.com
text:
Can there be an option to show both as well? First let me know if I understand the difference between Elapsed Time and Latency:

1) Latency - time to get first byte of response
2) Elapsed Time - time to get last byte of response

If this is the case, having both would show the developers that either there is a problem serializing the response or there may be a network issue. Having both would prevent us from having to run the test again.

creator: sebb@apache.org
text:
(In reply to comment #3)
> Can there be an option to show both as well? First let me know if I
> understand the difference between Elapsed Time and Latency:
> 
> 1) Latency - time to get first byte of response

Since responses arrive in chunks, it is actually time to first response.

> 2) Elapsed Time - time to get last byte of response
> 
> If this is the case, having both would show the developers that either there
> is a problem serializing the response or there may be a network issue.
> Having both would prevent us from having to run the test again.

They can both be seen in the raw sample log file.

Available in Report / Dashboard since 3.0.
Closing as wontfix.
creator: p.mouawad@ubik-ingenierie.com
